articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7b5 in G# (Shape: A)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: Dominant 7b5 in G# (Shape: A)

## Description:
The Dominant 7b5 chord is a complex and dissonant chord made up of the root note (G#), a major third (C#), diminished fifth (Eb) and minor seventh (F#). When played in this inversion (Shape: A), the notes are arranged in the order: G# (Root), C# (Major third), Eb (Diminished fifth), F# (Minor seventh). This chord creates a tense and unstable sound due to the combination of the diminished fifth and minor seventh.

## Notes and Intervals:

- G#: Root
- C#: Major third
- Eb: Diminished fifth
- F#: Minor seventh

## Genre and Flavor:
The Dominant 7b5 chord is commonly used in jazz, blues, and other genres where a sense of tension and resolution is desired. In jazz music, this chord is often used as a passing chord to create a sense of movement and chromaticism. The dissonant quality of the diminished fifth and minor seventh adds color and intensity to the harmonic progression, providing a rich and sophisticated musical flavor.

## Three Songs Featuring Dominant 7b5 in G# (Shape: A):
1. **"All Blues" by Miles Davis** - This jazz standard features the Dominant 7b5 chord in various harmonic contexts, showcasing its versatility and unique sound.
2. **"Blue Monk" by Thelonious Monk** - In this blues jazz composition, the Dominant 7b5 chord is used to add depth and complexity to the bluesy atmosphere.
3. **"So What" by Miles Davis** - Another iconic jazz piece that incorporates the Dominant 7b5 chord, contributing to the modal and evocative nature of the composition.
